summary: attitudes toward suicide among medical staff members have been associated with appropriate therapeutic responses to suicidal individuals. the aim of this study was to examine the effects of parental bonding on attitudes toward suicide among medical college students in japan. negative attitudes toward suicide such as anger could affect nontherapeutic reactions to suicidal individuals. a belief that suicide is a personal right was negatively related to suicide intervention skills. no study has evaluated the association between parental bonding and attitudes toward suicide among medical college students in Japan. the care dimension of the PBI reflects parental warmth and involvement in contrast to rejection and indifference. the overprotection dimension of the PBI reflects parental overprotection and control in contrast to the encouragement of autonomy. the data collection for this study was approved by the ethics committee of the Hirosaki University School of Medicine. subjects provided written informed consent before participating in the project. the data were analyzed using the PASW Statistics software program for Windows, version 18.0.
